The bills would lock that pledge into law.
The bills in both houses would start pilot projects within Medicare.
The bills in both chambers would create health insurance exchanges on which small businesses and individuals could choose from an array of private plans and possibly a public option.
The Senate bill would create an independent commission to monitor the pilot programs and recommend changes in Medicare's payment policies to urge providers to adopt reforms that work.
The Senate Finance bill would impose an excise tax ( ' ,  消费税) on health insurance plans that cost more than $8,000 for an individual or $21,000 for a family.
The House bill would authorize the secretary of health and human services to negotiate drug prices in Medicare and Medicaid.
The House bill has no similar tax.
Missing from these bills is any serious attempt to rein in malpractice costs.

Is surgery, radiation or careful monitoring best for prostate ( ' ,  前列腺) cancer? Is the latest and most expensive cholesterol-lowering drug any better than its common competitors? The pending bills would spend additional money to accelerate this effort.
Here are some of the important proposals in the House and Senate bills to try to address those problems, and why it is hard to know how well they will work.

Both bills would reduce the rate of growth in annual Medicare payments to hospitals, nursing homes and other providers by amounts comparable to the productivity savings routinely made in other industries with the help of new technologies and new ways to organize work.
As a result, the bills do not require, as they should, that the results of these studies be used to set payment rates in Medicare.

安排，预定，注定；预告(表演者或演出)，把…列入演出计划，安排…的演出(或放映)

jx.jx_en_mean: be suitable for a particular purpose
(informal)behave or talk in a very loving or sentimental way

entry.def: A bill is a written statement of money that you owe for goods or services.

example.ex: They couldn't afford to pay the bills...
example.tran: 他们无力支付这些账单。

example.ex: He paid his bill for the newspapers promptly.

entry.def: If you bill someone for goods or services you have provided them with, you give or send them a bill stating how much money they owe you for these goods or services.

example.ex: Are you going to bill me for this?
example.tran: 你们会给我开这个的账单吗？

entry.def: The bill in a restaurant is a piece of paper on which the price of the meal you have just eaten is written and which you are given before you pay.
A bill is a piece of paper money.

example.ex: ...a large quantity of US dollar bills.

entry.def: In government, a bill is a formal statement of a proposed new law that is discussed and then voted on.

example.ex: This is the toughest crime bill that Congress has passed in a decade...
example.tran: 这是十年来国会通过的最严厉的一项刑事法案。

example.ex: The bill was approved by a large majority.
example.tran: 这项法案得到了绝大多数人的支持。

entry.def: The bill of a show or concert is a list of the entertainers who will take part in it.
If someone is billed to appear in a particular show, it has been advertised that they are going to be in it.

example.ex: She was billed to play the Red Queen in Snow White.
example.tran: 海报宣传她会扮演《白雪公主》中的“红王后”。

entry.def: If you bill a person or event as a particular thing, you advertise them in a way that makes people think they have particular qualities or abilities.
entry.tran: 宣传（某人或某物有某种特质或能力）

example.ex: They bill it as Britain's most exciting museum.
example.tran: 他们宣称它是英国最有趣的博物馆。

entry.def: If you say that someone or something fits the bill or fills the bill, you mean that they are suitable for a particular job or purpose.

example.ex: If you fit the bill, send a CV to Rebecca Rees.
example.tran: 如果你符合要求，就寄一份简历给丽贝卡·里斯。

entry.def: If you have to foot the bill for something, you have to pay for it.

example.ex: Who is footing the bill for her extravagant holiday?
example.tran: 谁会为她奢侈的假日买单？

entry.def: If a doctor gives you a clean bill of health, they tell you that you are fit and healthy.

example.ex: President Mitterrand, 75, has been given a clean bill of health by doctors in Paris.
example.tran: 巴黎的医生们告诉75岁的密特朗总统，他的身体非常健康。

means.word_mean: 1. a statute in draft before it becomes law;

sentences.sentence: "they held a public hearing on the bill"

means.word_mean: 2. an itemized statement of money owed for goods shipped or services rendered;

sentences.sentence: "send me an account of what I owe"

means.word_mean: 3. a piece of paper money (especially one issued by a central bank);
4. the entertainment offered at a public presentation
5. a list of particulars (as a playbill or bill of fare)
6. an advertisement (usually printed on a page or in a leaflet) intended for wide distribution;

sentences.sentence: "he mailed the circular to all subscribers"

means.word_mean: 7. horny projecting mouth of a bird
8. a sign posted in a public place as an advertisement;
9. a long-handled saw with a curved blade;

sentences.sentence: "he used a bill to prune branches off of the tree"

means.word_mean: 10. a brim that projects to the front to shade the eyes;

sentences.sentence: "he pulled down the bill of his cap and trudged ahead"

means.word_mean: 1. demand payment;

sentences.sentence: "Will I get charged for this service?"
"We were billed for 4 nights in the hotel, although we stayed only 3 nights"

means.word_mean: 2. advertise especially by posters or placards;

sentences.sentence: "He was billed as the greatest tenor since Caruso"

means.word_mean: 3. publicize or announce by placards

derivation.yuyuan_name: Middle English  (denoting a written list or catalogue): from Anglo-Norman French bille, probably based on medieval Latin bulla 'seal, sealed document' (see also bull)
Old English  bile, of unknown origin
Old English  bil, of West Germanic origin; related to German Bille 'axe'
